seoContent.formulaExplanation: TDEE (Total Daily Energy Expenditure) is calculated by multiplying your BMR (Basal Metabolic Rate) by an activity level multiplier. BMR represents calories burned at rest using the Mifflin-St Jeor equation. Activity multipliers range from 1.2 (sedentary) to 1.9 (extremely active) based on lifestyle and exercise habits. This gives your total daily calorie needs to maintain current weight.
examples: A sedentary 35-year-old man weighing 75kg and 175cm tall has a BMR of 1,676 calories and TDEE of 2,250 calories (using 1.2x multiplier), burning about 574 calories through daily activities
A moderately active 28-year-old woman weighing 70kg and 170cm tall has a BMR of 1,400 calories and TDEE of 2,450 calories (using 1.55x multiplier), with significant calorie burn from regular exercise
A very active 25-year-old male athlete weighing 80kg and 185cm tall has a BMR of 1,900 calories and TDEE of 3,450 calories (using 1.725x multiplier), requiring high caloric intake to maintain weight
seoContent.whoShouldUse: Fitness enthusiasts tracking calorie expenditure, athletes calculating energy needs, individuals on weight loss or muscle gain programs, people changing activity levels, dietitians and nutritionists, those starting new exercise routines, and anyone wanting to understand their metabolic rate and daily energy requirements.
seoContent.importantNotes: TDEE calculations provide estimates based on average activity levels. Individual results may vary based on muscle mass, body composition, genetics, and specific exercise types. Track actual weight changes over 2-4 weeks and adjust calorie intake accordingly. For weight loss, create a moderate deficit (250-500 calories below TDEE). For weight gain, consume 250-500 calories above TDEE. Consult healthcare providers for medical conditions.

faqs.question: What's the difference between BMR and TDEE?
faqs.answer: BMR (Basal Metabolic Rate) is the calories your body burns at complete rest to maintain basic functions. TDEE (Total Daily Energy Expenditure) includes BMR plus all calories burned through daily activities, exercise, and digestion. TDEE represents your total daily calorie needs to maintain weight.

faqs.question: How accurate is TDEE calculation?
faqs.answer: TDEE calculations are estimates based on population averages. Accuracy depends on how well your activity level matches the selected category. For best results, choose the activity level that most closely matches your lifestyle. Track actual weight changes and adjust as needed - this provides the most accurate personalized data.

faqs.question: Why does TDEE vary so much between people?
faqs.answer: TDEE varies based on age, gender, weight, height, muscle mass, and activity level. Younger people, men, larger individuals, and those with more muscle mass have higher TDEE. Very active people burn significantly more calories daily than sedentary individuals doing the same activities.

faqs.question: How do I increase my TDEE?
faqs.answer: Increase TDEE by building muscle mass (higher BMR), increasing daily activity, adding exercise sessions, or choosing more active occupations. Even small changes like taking stairs instead of elevator or standing instead of sitting can add up. Resistance training is particularly effective for long-term TDEE increases.

faqs.question: Can I eat my TDEE to lose weight?
faqs.answer: Eating at TDEE maintains weight. For weight loss, consume 250-500 calories below TDEE daily for sustainable 0.5-1 lb weekly loss. Larger deficits can work short-term but often lead to muscle loss and metabolic slowdown. Focus on nutrient-dense foods and resistance training to preserve muscle.

faqs.question: Does metabolism slow down with age?
faqs.answer: Yes, BMR decreases about 1-2% per decade after age 20 due to muscle loss and hormonal changes. This lowers TDEE, so older adults may need fewer calories to maintain weight. Regular resistance training and adequate protein intake help maintain muscle mass and metabolic rate.

faqs.question: How does exercise affect TDEE?
faqs.answer: Exercise increases TDEE through immediate calorie burn and long-term muscle building. Resistance training boosts BMR by increasing muscle mass. Cardio burns calories during activity. Both types of exercise contribute to higher daily calorie expenditure and improved metabolic health.

faqs.question: Should I track my actual TDEE?
faqs.answer: Calculator estimates are good starting points, but tracking actual TDEE through weight changes and calorie intake provides more accurate data. Use the calculator as a guide, then adjust based on real results. Tools like fitness trackers can help estimate daily expenditure more precisely.

faqs.question: What's the difference between BMR and TDEE?
faqs.answer: BMR (Basal Metabolic Rate) is the calories your body burns at complete rest to maintain basic functions. TDEE (Total Daily Energy Expenditure) includes BMR plus all calories burned through daily activities, exercise, and digestion. TDEE represents your total daily calorie needs to maintain weight.

faqs.question: How accurate is TDEE calculation?
faqs.answer: TDEE calculations are estimates based on population averages. Accuracy depends on how well your activity level matches the selected category. For best results, choose the activity level that most closely matches your lifestyle. Track actual weight changes and adjust as needed - this provides the most accurate personalized data.

faqs.question: Why does TDEE vary so much between people?
faqs.answer: TDEE varies based on age, gender, weight, height, muscle mass, and activity level. Younger people, men, larger individuals, and those with more muscle mass have higher TDEE. Very active people burn significantly more calories daily than sedentary individuals doing the same activities.

faqs.question: How do I increase my TDEE?
faqs.answer: Increase TDEE by building muscle mass (higher BMR), increasing daily activity, adding exercise sessions, or choosing more active occupations. Even small changes like taking stairs instead of elevator or standing instead of sitting can add up. Resistance training is particularly effective for long-term TDEE increases.

faqs.question: Can I eat my TDEE to lose weight?
faqs.answer: Eating at TDEE maintains weight. For weight loss, consume 250-500 calories below TDEE daily for sustainable 0.5-1 lb weekly loss. Larger deficits can work short-term but often lead to muscle loss and metabolic slowdown. Focus on nutrient-dense foods and resistance training to preserve muscle.

faqs.question: Does metabolism slow down with age?
faqs.answer: Yes, BMR decreases about 1-2% per decade after age 20 due to muscle loss and hormonal changes. This lowers TDEE, so older adults may need fewer calories to maintain weight. Regular resistance training and adequate protein intake help maintain muscle mass and metabolic rate.

faqs.question: How does exercise affect TDEE?
faqs.answer: Exercise increases TDEE through immediate calorie burn and long-term muscle building. Resistance training boosts BMR by increasing muscle mass. Cardio burns calories during activity. Both types of exercise contribute to higher daily calorie expenditure and improved metabolic health.

faqs.question: Should I track my actual TDEE?
faqs.answer: Calculator estimates are good starting points, but tracking actual TDEE through weight changes and calorie intake provides more accurate data. Use the calculator as a guide, then adjust based on real results. Tools like fitness trackers can help estimate daily expenditure more precisely.

seoContent.introduction: Calculate your Total Daily Energy Expenditure (TDEE) with our comprehensive TDEE Calculator. Understanding your daily calorie burn rate is crucial for effective weight management, fitness planning, and achieving your health goals. Our calculator combines your basal metabolic rate with activity level adjustments to provide accurate TDEE calculations.
benefits: Calculate accurate daily calorie expenditure
Understand your Basal Metabolic Rate (BMR) contribution
See how activity level affects total calorie burn
Get personalized activity level categorization
Learn expected weight change rates
Make informed decisions about calorie intake vs expenditure
Support weight loss, maintenance, or muscle gain goals
Track the impact of lifestyle changes on metabolism
howToUse: Enter your current body weight in kilograms or pounds
Enter your height in centimeters or inches
Select your gender for accurate metabolic calculations
Enter your age for age-appropriate adjustments
Choose the activity level that best describes your typical daily routine
Optionally specify your exercise frequency for more precise calculations
Review your BMR, TDEE, and activity level analysis
seoContent.formulaExplanation: TDEE (Total Daily Energy Expenditure) is calculated by multiplying your BMR (Basal Metabolic Rate) by an activity level multiplier. BMR represents calories burned at rest using the Mifflin-St Jeor equation. Activity multipliers range from 1.2 (sedentary) to 1.9 (extremely active) based on lifestyle and exercise habits. This gives your total daily calorie needs to maintain current weight.
examples: A sedentary 35-year-old man weighing 75kg and 175cm tall has a BMR of 1,676 calories and TDEE of 2,250 calories (using 1.2x multiplier), burning about 574 calories through daily activities
A moderately active 28-year-old woman weighing 70kg and 170cm tall has a BMR of 1,400 calories and TDEE of 2,450 calories (using 1.55x multiplier), with significant calorie burn from regular exercise
A very active 25-year-old male athlete weighing 80kg and 185cm tall has a BMR of 1,900 calories and TDEE of 3,450 calories (using 1.725x multiplier), requiring high caloric intake to maintain weight
seoContent.whoShouldUse: Fitness enthusiasts tracking calorie expenditure, athletes calculating energy needs, individuals on weight loss or muscle gain programs, people changing activity levels, dietitians and nutritionists, those starting new exercise routines, and anyone wanting to understand their metabolic rate and daily energy requirements.
seoContent.importantNotes: TDEE calculations provide estimates based on average activity levels. Individual results may vary based on muscle mass, body composition, genetics, and specific exercise types. Track actual weight changes over 2-4 weeks and adjust calorie intake accordingly. For weight loss, create a moderate deficit (250-500 calories below TDEE). For weight gain, consume 250-500 calories above TDEE. Consult healthcare providers for medical conditions.
